newsitem.title: USA: World Bank reorganization price tag is reduced.
newsitem.headline: World Bank reorganization price tag is reduced.

text.p: The World Bank said on Friday the price tag for a sweeping reorganization proposal has been cut significantly, in response to widespread criticism from the United States Congress and elsewhere.

Bank officials estimated the proposal would reduce the expense of cutting staff and changing the Bank's focus by about $122 million from $420 million, and the final plan would be decided before the executive board on March 20.

Most of the reorganization at the huge lending institution would take 30 months instead of the two years to complete as originally proposed. Bank President James Wolfensohn said he planned to closely monitor payoffs to departing employees.
The original price tag for the plan was $420 million, of which $250 million would be paid for by bank earnings and the remainder would come from internal savings.
In addition, the bank expected to pay $100 to $150 million for the severance packages of 500 to 700 employees that were being targeted.
The goal of the plan was to put more personnel in the front line of helping countries, while reducing so-called support people who work in the background in the huge Bank bureaucracy.
In a statement to the board, however, Wolfensohn said the plan was not just to save money but "an attempt to make the institution an effective instrument for development."
The Bank has come under fire for years for being bloated and inefficient, and the cost of reorganization was added to these charges although Wolfensohn maintained it would streamline operations.
